headline: S&P 500, Nasdaq Mark Record Closes Despite Trade Hiccups
summary: The S&P and the Nasdaq each rose 0.5% for the day, closing out a tumultuous session driven by trade headlines.  Stocks faltered earlier Friday afternoon, after President Donald Trump announced the U.S. is shutting all trade discussions with Canada, in retaliation to Canada's decision to proceed with a tax targeting U.S. technology companies like Meta.  Trump, in a post on Truth Social, said the U.S. will decide the tariff rate on the Canada in the next seven days, essentially shutting down negotiations with a top trading partner.

headline: Meta seeks $29 billion from private capital firms for AI data centers, FT reports
summary: The Facebook-parent has advanced discussions with private credit investors including Apollo Global Management, KKR, Brookfield, Carlyle and PIMCO, the report said, citing people familiar with the matter.  Meta is looking to raise $3 billion in equity and $26 billion in debt, the report said, adding that the company is debating how to structure the debt raising and may also seek to raise more capital.  Such a fundraising comes at a time when Meta has doubled down its commitment to artificial intelligence, including a $14.8 billion investment in startup Scale AI.

Such a fundraising comes at a time when Meta has doubled down its commitment to artificial intelligence, including a $14.8 billion investment in startup Scale AI.

headline: Alphabet Stock Is Having a Bad Year. How AI Can Make or Break the Google Parent.
summary: Google has an edge over OpenAI in one important metric, argues Citizens JMP analyst Andrew Boone.  OpenAI,which created ChatGPT, has 800 million weekly active users compared to some 5 billion for Google.  Boone upgraded Alphabet stock to Outperform from Market Perform and set a $220 price target on the shares.

headline: Exclusive-Meta says EU antitrust regulators are discriminating against its business model
summary: Meta Platforms on Friday criticised EU antitrust regulators for moving the goalpost as the U.S. company seeks to comply with an order targeting its pay-or-consent business model. The tech giant said the European Commission had discriminated against its business model and that it had nevertheless engaged constructively in discussions and introduced extensive changes. "We are confident that the range of choices we offer people in the EU doesn't just comply with what the EU's rules require - it goes well beyond them," a Meta spokesperson said.

raw.headline: Exclusive-Meta says EU antitrust regulators are discriminating against its business model
raw.summary: Meta Platforms on Friday criticised EU antitrust regulators for moving the goalpost as the U.S. company seeks to comply with an order targeting its pay-or-consent business model. The tech giant said the European Commission had discriminated against its business model and that it had nevertheless engaged constructively in discussions and introduced extensive changes. "We are confident that the range of choices we offer people in the EU doesn't just comply with what the EU's rules require - it goes well beyond them," a Meta spokesperson said.

headline: Meta, Anthropic win legal battles over AI 'training.' The copyright war is far from over.

raw.headline: Meta, Anthropic win legal battles over AI 'training.' The copyright war is far from over.

headline: Meta may face daily fines over pay-or-consent model, EU warns
summary: BRUSSELS (Reuters) -Meta Platforms may face daily fines if EU regulators decide the changes it has proposed to its pay-or-consent model fail to comply with an antitrust order issued in April, they said on Friday.  The warning from the European Commission, which acts as the EU competition enforcer, came two months after it slapped a 200-million-euro ($234 million) fine on the U.S. social media giant for breaching the Digital Markets Act (DMA) aiming at curbing the power of Big Tech.  The move shows the Commission's continuing crackdown against Big Tech and its push to create a level playing field for smaller rivals despite U.S. criticism about the bloc's rules mainly targeting its companies.

raw.headline: Meta may face daily fines over pay-or-consent model, EU warns
raw.summary: BRUSSELS (Reuters) -Meta Platforms may face daily fines if EU regulators decide the changes it has proposed to its pay-or-consent model fail to comply with an antitrust order issued in April, they said on Friday.  The warning from the European Commission, which acts as the EU competition enforcer, came two months after it slapped a 200-million-euro ($234 million) fine on the U.S. social media giant for breaching the Digital Markets Act (DMA) aiming at curbing the power of Big Tech.  The move shows the Commission's continuing crackdown against Big Tech and its push to create a level playing field for smaller rivals despite U.S. criticism about the bloc's rules mainly targeting its companies.
